Guiyang, Guizhou 550025, China Department of Chemical Engineering, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Guizhou University Guiyang Guizhou 550025 China Converting CO2 into light olefins (C2 =–C4 =) using oxide–zeolite bifunctional catalyst is a new strategy for producing light olefins. Herein, a series of bifunctional catalysts comprising In-doped GaZrOx oxides and SAPO-34 molecular sieves for CO2 hydrogenation to light olefins are reported, and their catalytic mechanisms are investigated using in situ spectroscopy. After optimizing the In doping amount, oxide calcination temperature, oxide coupling mode with SAPO-34, and reaction conditions, the bifunctional catalysts achieved 82.8% C2 =–C4 = selectivity, 24% CO2 conversion, and up to 10.1% C2 =–C4 = yield. Furthermore, no considerable deactivation was observed after 100 h of the reaction. Various characterization and experimental results indicate that adding In to GaZrOx promotes oxygen-vacancy generation and enhances the adsorption activation of CO2 and H2, thereby promoting the formation of formate (HCOO*) and methoxy (CH3O*) intermediates and improving the catalytic performance of the C2 =–C4 = synthesis from CO2. Graphical abstract ga1 Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Light olefins Bifunctional catalyst Ternary metal oxides Indium promotes Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Owing to the excessive use of fossil fuels, the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere has increased considerably. Excessive CO2 emissions have contributed to the greenhouse effect and global warming, causing a series of environmental and ecological problems. Therefore, CO2 capture and utilization has become a global research hotspot [1,2]. Although CO2 is a greenhouse gas, it is also an abundant, nontoxic carbon source [3,4]. CO2 is used as a feedstock for synthesizing a range of high-value-added chemicals, such as formic acid [5–7], methanol [8,9], light olefins [10,11], and aromatics [12–14]. Light olefins are an important raw material for producing plastics, fibers, and other chemicals mainly obtained by fossil resource cracking and light alkane dehydrogenation [15]. Using CO2 as a renewable carbon source for synthesizing light olefins will alleviate the energy crisis caused by the depletion of fossil fuels, promote the carbon cycle, and slow the growth of CO2 levels in the atmosphere [16]. Two main reaction pathways for converting CO2 into C2 =–C4 = are the following: the Fischer−Tropsch pathway and the MeOH-mediated pathway. However, the Fischer−Tropsch pathway is constrained by the Anderson–Schulz–Flory (ASF) limit, and the low-carbon olefin selectivity does not exceed 58%. Therefore, the MeOH-mediated pathway has received much attention because it can break the ASF limit and greatly improve the selectivity of light olefins [17]. In 2017, Li et al. presented a ZnZrOx/SAPO-34 bifunctional catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to C2 =–C4 = with up to 80% C2 =–C4 = selectivity and 12.6% CO2 conversion [17]. In the bifunctional catalyst, the metal oxide is responsible for hydrogenating CO2 into methanol, whereas the molecular sieve is responsible for converting the resulting methanol into C2 =–C4 = (i.e., C–C coupling) [18]. Bifunctional catalysts have recently been widely used for CO2 hydrogenation to C2 =–C4 =. Metal oxides, such as Mn2O3–ZnO [19], ZnGa2O4 [20], In−Zr [21,22], and ZnAl2O4 [23], have been combined with SAPO-34 for successfully hydrogenating CO2 into light olefins. These results suggest that the use of metal oxides and zeolite bifunctional catalysts is a promising strategy for a highly selective conversion of CO2 into C2 =–C4 = via the formation of methanol intermediates. The key for improving the catalytic performance of bifunctional catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to C2 =–C4 = is to promote more methanol intermediates to be generated on the metal oxide and then, rapidly converted into C2 =–C4 = on the zeolite molecular sieve. This requires a rational adjustment of the surface electronic structure and properties of the metal oxides to enhance the adsorption and activation of CO2 and H2, along with a simultaneous adjustment of the proximity of the metal oxides to the molecular sieve [24]. Introducing dopants into metal oxides is an effective strategy for modulating their surface electronic structure [25]. In this work, we propose the introduction of In as a dopant into a GaZrOx solid solution to prepare a series of In-modified GaZrOx(x% In) oxides and then, combining them with SAPO-34 for a catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 into C2 =–C4 =. According to various characterization results, introducing an appropriate amount of In and a controlled calcination temperature could simultaneously improve the adsorption and activation of CO2 with H2 and form more HCOO* and CH3O* intermediates to facilitate methanol synthesis. GaZrOx(3% In)/SAPO-34 composite catalysts showed 24% CO2 conversion at 380 °C and 3.0 MPa in the CO2-hydrogenation reaction. The C2 =–C4 = selectivity reached 82.8%, whereas the CO selectivity was only 49%. The C2 =–C4 = yield was as high as 10.1%, and the catalytic performance remained high even after 100 h of reaction. 2 Experimental (1) Synthesis of GaZrOx(x% In). A series of GaZrOx(x% In) oxides, where x represents the molar percentage of In in In +Ga + Zr, were prepared through the coprecipitation method. Fixed Ga molar percentage of 20%. First, desired amounts of In(NO3)3, Ga(NO3)2·6 H2O, and Zr(NO3)4·5 H2O were dissolved into deionized water in a flask. Next, a 1 mol/L (NH4)2CO3 aqueous solution was added into the abovementioned mixture with a 3 mL/min rate under vigorous magnetic stirring at 70 °C until the pH of the solution became 7.0. After 2 h of aging under stirring conditions at 70 °C, the suspension was cooled to room temperature and washed thrice with deionized water. The obtained precipitate was dried overnight at 110 ℃ and calcined at 550 °C for 3 h in static air. According to the In amount, the obtained samples were labeled as GaZrOx(x% In) (x = 1, 3, 5, 7, and 10). GaZrOx was prepared using a similar method but without adding indium nitrate.The calcination temperature of the colloidal precursors for GaZrOx(3% In) was changed from 450 °C to 650 °C. The obtained samples were labeled as GaZrOx(3% In)− 450 °C, GaZrOx(3% In)− 550 °C, and GaZrOx(3% In)− 650 °C. (2) Synthesis of SAPO-34. SAPO-34 zeolite was synthesized by hydrothermal synthesis according to a previous report [26]. The gel was synthesized using the unprocessed materials of quasizeolites, phosphoric acid, tetraethyl silicate, morpholine, and deionized water in a 1.0 Al2O3:0.8 P2O5:0.6 SiO2:2.5 MOR:80 H2O molar ratio. The desired amounts of quasizeolites, morpholine, phosphoric acid, tetraethyl silicate, and deionized water were briefly stirred at room temperature for 24 h to form a colloidal sol. The suspension was then transferred to a 200 mL teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. Crystallization was performed at 200 °C for 48 h. Subsequently, the suspension was centrifuged and washed thrice with deionized water and ethanol, respectively. The resulting precipitate was dried overnight at 110 °C and calcined in air at 550 °C for 6 h. (3) Synthesis of bifunctional catalyst. The GaZrOx(x% In)/SAPO-34 bifunctional catalyst was prepared by mixing GaZrOx(x% In) oxide with SAPO-34 zeolite powder at a 2:1 mass ratio, crushing, and then sifting to a 20–40 mesh. Other approaches, such as the particle stacking and double-bed methods, are also used for the assembly of two components. In the particle stacking method, the GaZrOx(x% In) oxide and zeolite powder are compressed into tablets, crushed and screened to a 20–40 mesh, and then evenly mixed according to the 2:1 mass ratio. In the double-bed method, the GaZrOx(x% In) oxide and zeolite powder are compressed into tablets and screened to a 20–40 mesh. The GaZrOx(x% In) and SAPO-34 particles are then separated by quartz sand, and the GaZrOx(x% In):SAPO-34 ratio is maintained at 2:1. 2.1 Catalyst evaluation A pressurized fixed-bed reactor was used to evaluate the catalytic performance of the tandem catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to lower olefins. The catalyst (0.50 g) with a grain size of 20–40 mesh was loaded in a quartz tube with an 8.0 mm inner diameter embedded in a stainless steel tubular reactor. The catalyst was pretreated in a H2 stream (30 mL/min) at 380 °C for 2 h before the reaction. Next, a gas mixture with a volume ratio of V(H2)/V(CO2)/V(N2) = 3/1/0.17 was introduced. The reaction products were determined online using a Shimadzu GC-2014 C gas chromatograph equipped with thermal conductivity and flame ionization detectors. The catalytic performance was analyzed after 24 h of reaction. The CO2 conversion (X(CO2)) and CO selectivity (S(CO)) were calculated as follows based on carbon atoms: X CO 2 = n CO 2 , in − n ( CO 2 , out ) n ( CO 2 , in ) × 100 % S CO = n ( CO , out ) n CO 2 , in − n ( CO 2 , out ) × 100 % , where n(CO2, in) is the molar amount of CO2 entering the reactor; n(CO2, out) is the molar amount of CO2 exiting the reactor; and n(CO, out) is the molar amount of CO exiting the reactor. Hydrocarbons and CO were the final products of the CO2 conversion reaction. The selectivity of the total hydrocarbons (S(CH)) was calculated as follows: S CH = ∑ 1 i i ∙ n ( C i H m , out ) n CO 2 , in − n CO 2 , out − n ( CO , out ) × 100 % The C2 =–C4 = (S(C2 =–C4 =)) selectivity was calculated as follows on a molar carbon basis in the total hydrocarbons: S C 2 = – C 4 = = 2 n C 2 H 4 + 3 n C 3 H 6 + 4 n C 4 H 8 n CO 2 , in − n CO 2 , out − n ( CO , out ) × 100 % where the CiHm outlet represents moles C of individual hydrocarbon products at the outlet. n(C2H4), n(C3H6), and n(C4H8) are the molar amounts of C2H4, C3H6, and C4H8, respectively, in the effluent from the reactor. The C2 =–C4 = (Y(C2 =–C4 =)) yield was obtained according to the following: Y C 2 = – C 4 = = X ( C O 2 ) × [ 1 − S ( CO ) ] × S ( C 2 = – C 4 = ) × 100 % . 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity evaluation Fig. 1 shows the performance of CO2 hydrogenation to C2 =–C4 = over a bifunctional catalyst. The effect of different In doping on the catalytic performance is depicted in Fig. 1a. On GaZrOx/SAPO-34, the CO2 conversion was 18.2% at 380 °C and the selectivity of CO produced by the reverse water–gas shift (RWGS) reaction was as high as 54.3% at 380 °C, while the C2 =–C4 = yield was only 6.8%. After introducing In, the CO2 conversion gradually increased and reached a maximum of 24% on GaZrOx(3% In)/SAPO-34 and the CO selectivity dropped to a minimum of 49%, whereas the C2 =–C4 = selectivity reached 82.8%. After introducing more In, the CO2 conversion decreased to 17.1%, CO selectivity increased to 59.8%, and light olefin selectivity decreased to 70%. In other words, introducing an appropriate amount of In to GaZrOx not only improves the CO2 conversion but also inhibits the CO formation and improves the C2 =–C4 = selectivity and yield. These results are superior to those reported in a previous study (Table S1, supporting information, SI). The CO2 hydrogenation reaction was performed at different reaction temperatures and pressures to evaluate the effect of the reaction conditions on the catalytic performance. As illustrated in Fig. 1b, the CO2 conversion increased as the reaction temperature increased from 360 °C to 400 °C; the CO selectivity also increased because of the promotion of the RWGS reaction. However, the CO selectivity remained < 50% at 380 °C. Fig. 1 c shows that decreasing the reaction pressure at 380 °C can improve the C2 =–C4 = selectivity by inhibiting the excessive hydrogenation of C2 =–C4 = to the corresponding alkanes. Increasing the reaction pressure favors CO2 conversion and methanol formation. When the reaction pressure increased from 0.5 to 4.0 MPa, the CO selectivity decreased from 63.1% to 47.4% and the CO2 conversion increased from 8.4% to 25.4%. The increase in the reaction pressure not only inhibits the RWGS reaction and reduces the formation of CO by-products but also causes an excessive hydrogenation of C2 =–C4 =, reducing the C2 =–C4 = selectivity. The catalytic performance of bifunctional catalysts in CO2 hydrogenation is also related to the air velocity in the reaction and the calcination temperature of the GaZrOx(3% In) colloidal precursor. Increasing the air velocity substantially improves the light olefin selectivity while reducing the formation of C2 0–C4 0 and CO (Fig. 1 d). However, the CO2 conversion is also reduced owing to a short contact time between the catalyst and feed gas. When the calcination temperature of the GaZrOx(3% In) colloidal precursor increased from 450 °C to 650 °C, the CO2 conversion and C2 =–C4 = selectivity gradually decreased because of a decrease in the GaZrOx(3% In) oxygen-vacancy concentration (Fig. S1, supporting information, SI). To gain insight into the effect of the mixing mode of oxides and molecular sieves on the catalytic performance, GaZrOx(3% In) was mixed with the SAPO-34 molecular sieve in different ways. As shown in Fig. 2, the bilayer-bed catalyst with GaZrOx(3% In) in the upper layer of quartz sand and SAPO-34 in the lower layer showed 21.6% CO2 conversion and 80.4% CO selectivity. The large distance between different active centers limits the efficiency of the bifunctional catalyst for hydrocarbon production, promotes the RWGS reaction, and enables the production of more CO by-products. To shorten the tandem spacing, we sieved GaZrOx (3% In) oxide and SAPO-34 molecular sieves to 20–40 mesh, respectively, and then shook and mixed the oxide particles and zeolite particles together in a vessel according to a mass ratio of 2:1 to increase the proximity of the two components and to keep the distance between the oxide and SAPO-34 in the range of μm [27]. The CO2 conversion increased to 25.2%, CO selectivity reduced to 67%, and C2 =–C4 = selectivity reached 62.9% in the mixing mode with two active-center particles stacked. In order to further reduce the tandem spacing, the powder mixture of these two compositions was ground in an agate mortar and then the obtained powder mixture was sieved to 20–40 mesh, the distance between the oxides obtained by this method and SAPO-34 was in the range of nm [28]. The combined catalysts showed high activity and low separation with 24% CO2 conversion, 82.8% C2 =–C4 = selectivity, and 49% CO selectivity. Wang et al. reported that close contact between In2O3 and zeolite molecular sieves under harsh reaction conditions resulted in the migration of oxide components or their reduced species to the zeolite surface to cover the strong acid centre of the zeolite, which in turn destroyed the bifunctional catalyst and led to the lack of light olefins in the hydrogenation products [29]. However, in this work as the contact distance between the oxide and the molecular sieve decreases, the selectivity of the light olefins gradually increases, suggesting that in this work In species did not migrate to the surface of the molecular sieve and poison the strong acid sites. The order-of-magnitude comparison of C2 =–C4 = yields for the abovementioned three combinations: physical milling > particle stacking > double bed. This was a synergistic effect caused by a better relaying of different reaction steps between closely adjacent active centers, which enhanced the activity of the tandem catalysts while suppressing the RWGS reaction. Fig. 3 shows the effect of the GaZrOx(3% In)/SAPO-34 mass ratio on the catalytic performance. The C2 =–C4 = selectivity gradually increased to 86% when the GaZrOx(3% In)/SAPO-34 mass ratio decreased from 4:1–1:4. In contrast, the CO2 conversion and the CO selectivity decreased with the decreasing GaZrOx(3% In)/SAPO-34 mass ratio. The C2 =–C4 = yield reached the maximum at the 2:1 GaZrOx(3% In)/SAPO-34 mass ratio, indicating that the two-component coupling was the best. Excessive GaZrOx(3% In) oxide and limited SAPO-34 molecular sieve will promote the RWGS reaction and produce an excessive amount of CO, which is not conducive to the C2 =–C4 = production. Limited GaZrOx(3% In) oxide will lead to a lower CO2 conversion, which is not conducive to CO2 conversion. Therefore, the oxide/SAPO-34 mass ratio is also critical to the catalytic performance of CO2 hydrogenation. Fig. 4 demonstrates the stability of the GaZrOx(3% In)/SAPO-34 tandem catalyst. Under the reaction conditions of 380 ℃ and 3.0 MPa, the activity of the tandem catalyst slightly decreased after 100 h of reaction, this is due to the fact that coke was gradually formed during the reaction and covered the active site of SAPO-34, and the formed coke also accumulated in the narrow pore of the eight-membered ring to blocked the transport pathway, thus leading to a decrease in the activity of SAPO-34, and consequently a decrease in the selectivity of the light olefins and the CO2 conversion rate [30–32]. However, the catalyst still maintained 20.59% CO2 conversion and 75.00% C2 =–C4 = selectivity, indicating that the catalyst had good catalytic stability. 3.2 Catalyst structure The crystal structure of the catalyst was investigated through XRD. Fig. 5a shows the characteristic peaks of 30.5°, 35.0°, 50.8°, 60.5°, 63.5°, 74.9°, 83.1°, and 85.6° in the GaZrOx solid-solution catalyst identified as a tetragonal phase of ZrO2 (t-ZrO2, PDF#50–1089). The diffraction peaks of GaZrOx(x% In) were similar to those of the GaZrOx solid solution, indicating that In doping did not significantly change the crystal structure of the catalyst. The characteristic diffraction peaks of the In2O3 phase were also not detected on GaZrOx(x% In), indicating that In may be highly dispersed on the GaZrOx solid solution. The ionic radius of In3+ (0.80 Å) is smaller than that of Zr4+ (0.84 Å); hence, if In3+ is doped into the ZrO2 lattice, the crystal plane spacing of ZrO2 will decrease, and the diffraction angle will increase. Fig. 5b and S1 depict that the diffraction peak at 2θ = 30.5° shifts to a higher angle, and the crystallographic spacing of ZrO2 decreases when the In content is increased from 1% to 10% (Table S2). This suggests that In species may be doped into the GaZrOx oxide lattice [33]. Fig. 6 displays the TEM and HRTEM images of GaZrOx and GaZrOx(x% In), which clearly show both as nanoparticles. The HRTEM image depicts a lattice spacing of 0.293 nm for GaZrOx, which corresponds to the (011) crystal plane of t-ZrO2. As expected, the lattice spacing corresponding to the (011) crystal plane of GaZrOx(x% In) gradually decreased. The (011) lattice spacing of t-ZrO2 decreased to 0.291 nm when the In doping was increased to 10%. This result agreed with the XRD results and further confirmed In doping in the GaZrOx binary oxide lattice. The EDX pattern analysis demonstrated that the In and Ga elements were highly uniformly distributed on ZrO2 (Figs. 6e and 6f). Based on these facts, GaZrOx(x% In) can be reasonably inferred as in the solid-solution state. N2 adsorption–desorption was used to determine the BET surface area. Table S3 summarizes the pore size data for GaZrOx and GaZrOx(x% In). Fig. 7 presents the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and the pore size distribution curves of these catalysts. According to the nomenclature of the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry, all samples exhibited Type-IV adsorption isotherms with hysteresis loops, indicating the presence of mesopores in the structure of these samples. In Table S3, the BET surface area of GaZrOx is 19.13 m2/g, while that of the GaZrOx(x% In) ternary oxide catalyst ranges from 20.85 to 29.04 m2/g, which is significantly higher than that of GaZrOx. The BET surface area showed a volcanic distribution with the In addition, and GaZrOx(3% In) demonstrated the largest BET surface area. This result confirmed that the introduction of In affected the structural properties of the GaZrOx oxides. The surface electronic structures and states of GaZrOx and GaZrOx(x% In) were investigated using XPS. Two peaks at 182.1 and 184.5 eV, which corresponded to Zr4+ 3d5/2 and Zr4+ 3d3/2, respectively, were observed in the Zr (3d) XPS spectrum of GaZrOx ( Fig. 8a), as well as two peaks at 1117.6 and 1144.5 eV, which corresponded to Ga3+ 2p3/2 and Ga3+ 2p1/2, respectively (Fig. 8b). In contrast, the binding energies at both In 3d5/2 and In 3d3/2 are increasing (Fig. S2, SI), and the binding energies at Ga 2p3/2 and Ga 2p1/2 are similar due to the fact that the molar percentage of Ga in the GaZrOx(x% In) oxide is fixed at 20%. This indicates that In interacts with GaZrOx and influences the chemical environment of Zr [34]. Moreover, more electron transfer and stronger interactions were observed with the increase in In doping. The oxygen vacancies in metal oxides are essential for CO2 activation and methanol formation [34–36]. The O (1 s) XPS spectra (Fig. 8c) results show that three oxygen types are present in the GaZrOx and GaZrOx(x% In) samples. The peaks located at 529.5–530.5 eV are attributed to lattice oxygen (OL). Those at 530.5–531.5 eV are associated with the oxygen atoms near the surface oxygen vacancies (OV). Lastly, the peaks at 531.5–532.5 eV are attributed to the hydroxyl group (OOH) [21,37]. The OV concentration was calculated using the OV/(OV + OL) formula. In Fig. 8 c and Table S4, the OV concentration increased, and then decreased with the doping increase. The OV concentration reached a maximum of 33.21% under 3% In doping, confirming that the appropriate amount of doping is beneficial to the formation of a large number of oxygen vacancies on the surface. The oxygen-vacancy concentration of the metal oxides was further characterized by EPR [38]. Fig. 8d illustrates that this signal increased, and then decreased with the increasing In doping. GaZrOx(3% In) showed the largest EPR signal compared to the other samples, which was consistent with the XPS results. The oxygen-vacancy concentration also depends on the roasting temperature of the colloidal precursors. The GaZrOx(3% In) crystallinity was significantly increased when the roasting temperature was increased from 450 °C to 650 °C. However, the oxygen-vacancy concentration first increased, and then decreased and acquired the maximum oxygen-vacancy concentration at 550 °C calcination (Fig. S3, SI). The reduction of the GaZrOx and GaZrOx(x% In) oxides was investigated using H2-TPR. Fig. 9a presents the H2-TPR curves for all the catalysts. For the GaZrOx solid-solution catalyst, only one H2 depletion peak (β) was observed at 679 °C, which corresponded to the partial reduction of the bulk-phase ZrO2 [39,40]. For the GaZrOx(x% In) solid-solution catalysts, the reduction peaks were observed in the 200–400 °C range and attributable to the partial reduction of surface indium species accompanied by the formation of the surface OV [41–43]. It is observed that GaZrOx(3% In) consumed more H2 in this range than the other samples, which further confirmed that GaZrOx(3% In) had more defective sites. Meanwhile, two H2 consumption peaks were observed in the 400–800 °C range. The α peak can be attributed to the complete reduction of the In species to the metal In [44,45]. The β peak corresponded to the partial reduction of the bulk-phase ZrO2. With the In doping increase, the α peak moved toward the low temperature and gradually decreased in intensity, while the β peak moved toward the high temperature. In other words, the In species is more difficult to reduce with GaZrOx, and the In GaZrOx interaction becomes stronger as the In doping increases. Previous studies have pointed out that the OV in oxide catalysts facilitate CO2 adsorption [46,47]. The CO2 adsorption capacity of the catalyst was investigated herein by using the CO2-TPD of the catalyst. Fig. 9 b shows the CO2-TPD curves. The desorption peaks below 120 °C are attributed to the physically adsorbed CO2, while those above 120–350 °C and 350–500 °C are attributed to the weak and strong chemisorption of CO2 on the surface OV [48]. GaZrOx(3% In) exhibited a greater CO2 desorption at 120–350 °C, which confirmed a higher oxygen-vacancy concentration compared to the other samples. The H2-TPD curve is shown in Fig. 9 c; the addition of In also enhanced the H2 adsorption capacity of the catalyst. Grinding and mixing SAPO-34 with GaZrOx(3% In) oxide did not affect their crystal structures (Fig. S4a, SI). The prepared SAPO-34 zeolites had a cubic structure, measured approximately 1.5 µm (Fig. S4b, SI), and had a CHA topology and a high crystallinity. The SEM images show that the GaZrOx(3% In) particles are dispersed on the SAPO-34 crystal surface (Fig. 4c, SI). 3.3 Reaction mechanism The reaction mechanism of the methanol synthesis by CO2 hydrogenation on GaZrOx and GaZrOx(x% In) was investigated using in situ DRIFTS. In Fig. 10a, the peaks at 1587, 1362, 1290, 2968, and 2882 cm−1 were attributed to HCOO* [43,49,50], those at 2824 and 1140 cm−1 were attributed to CH3O* [43,51,52], and that at 1456 cm−1 observed on GaZrOx after the passage of the CO2/H2 mixture at 300 °C was attributed to the carbonate species (CO3 2−) [8], confirming the formation of formate and methoxy intermediates. These results suggest that the HCOO* and CH3O* species are the main intermediate species in the CO2-hydrogenation reaction over the GaZrOx solid-solution catalysts. In addition, the methanol synthesis in this catalytic system follows the carbonate–formate–methoxy pathway. The GaZrOx(3% In) and in situ DRIFTS during CO2 hydrogenation are presented in Fig. 10b. After the CO2/H2 mixture was introduced at 300 °C, the HCOO* species were detected at 1587, 1362, 1290, 2968, and 2882 cm−1, whereas the CH3O* species were detected at 1140 and 2824 cm−1. The IR bands of the HCOO* and CH3O* species for CO2 hydrogenation on GaZrOx(3% In) were similar to those on GaZrOx, indicating that CO2 conversion into methanol on GaZrOx(3% In) also followed the carbonate–formate–methoxy pathway. However, some new IR bands, which were attributed to CH3O* , were observed at 1047 and 2928 cm−1, implying that the HCOO* hydrogenation into CH3O* was promoted by In. The IR band intensity of HCOO* and CH3O* for GaZrOx (3% In) was much larger than that of GaZrOx, whereas that of CO3 2− was much smaller than that of GaZrOx. These results indicate that adding In enhances the rate of the HCOO* and CH3O* production. Fig. 10c shows the in situ DRIFTS of GaZrOx(10% In) during CO2 hydrogenation. The IR spectrum of GaZrOx(10% In) was similar to that of GaZrOx after the CO2/H2 mixture was introduced at 300 °C. In other words, GaZrOx (10% In) also followed the carbonate–formate–methoxy pathway. However, the IR band intensities of HCOO* and CH3O* of GaZrOx(10% In) were much smaller than those of GaZrOx and GaZrOx (3% In). This finding confirms that introducing a higher amount of In species will hinder the formation of the HCOO* and CH3O* intermediates and is detrimental to methanol formation. The effect of different In doping on the catalytic performance of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol is shown in Fig. S5. On GaZrOx, the CO2 conversion was 11.2% at 320 °C and the methanol selectivity was 45.3%. After the introduction of In, the CO2 conversion reached a maximum value of 13.7% and the CH3OH selectivity reached 49.7% on GaZrOx (3% In). On GaZrOx (10% In), the conversion of CO2 decreased to 8.6% and the selectivity of CH3OH decreased to 39.5%. The above indicates that the introduction of appropriate amount of In into GaZrOx not only improves the CO2 conversion, but also promotes the formation of CH3OH. This is consistent with the in situ IR results. 4 Conclusions In summary, we prepared a series of In-promoted In–Ga–Zr ternary solid-solution oxides and SAPO-34 composites for CO2 hydrogenation to light olefins. When the In content was optimized to 3% and coupled with SAPO-34, the CO2 conversion increased from 18.2% to 24% at 380 °C and 3 MPa. The yield of the low-carbon olefins increased from 6.8% to 10.1%, and the CO selectivity decreased to 49%. The low-carbon olefin selectivity remained essentially unchanged, and a high catalytic performance was maintained even after 100 h of reaction. According to the chemisorption, EPR, and in-situ-IR results, adding an appropriate amount of In and a controlled calcination temperature would generate more OV, promoting CO2 activation and the formation of HCOO* and CH3O* intermediates, thereby increasing the production rate of HCOO* and CH3O* . However, introducing an excessive amount of In will hinder the formation of the HCOO* and CH3O* intermediates, which is detrimental to methanol formation and leads to the production of more CO. This work provides a simple, effective method for regulating the concentration of OV on the surface of metal oxides, which will help in designing effective bifunctional catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to low-carbon olefins. coredata.dc:description: Converting CO2 into light olefins (C2 =–C4 =) using oxide–zeolite bifunctional catalyst is a new strategy for producing light olefins. Herein, a series of bifunctional catalysts comprising In-doped GaZrOx oxides and SAPO-34 molecular sieves for CO2 hydrogenation to light olefins are reported, and their catalytic mechanisms are investigated using in situ spectroscopy. After optimizing the In doping amount, oxide calcination temperature, oxide coupling mode with SAPO-34, and reaction conditions, the bifunctional catalysts achieved 82.8% C2 =–C4 = selectivity, 24% CO2 conversion, and up to 10.1% C2 =–C4 = yield. Furthermore, no considerable deactivation was observed after 100 h of the reaction. Various characterization and experimental results indicate that adding In to GaZrOx promotes oxygen-vacancy generation and enhances the adsorption activation of CO2 and H2, thereby promoting the formation of formate (HCOO*) and methoxy (CH3O*) intermediates and improving the catalytic performance of the C2 =–C4 = synthesis from CO2.
coredata.dc:title: Bifunctional catalyst consisting of In-modified GaZrOx ternary solid solution oxide and SAPO-34 for efficiently converting CO2 into light olefins
